  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Good afternoon,
 
Katie’s on assignment today. This is Anthony
  Mason filling in.
 
CBS News reported today that the patient with
  extreme drug-resistant tuberculosis is 31-year-old Atlanta lawyer Andrew Haley Speaker. In a strange
  twist, Speaker’s new father-in-law is a government scientist who has
  studied tuberculosis – but he says there’s no connection to his
  son-in-law’s infection. Kelly Cobiella will have the very latest on
  this evolving story and will also tell us how the public is reacting. Also, the
  ease in which the patient crossed the country’s border has exposed
  cracks in the national security system. Nancy Cordes will look at what this
  case can illustrate about our country’s preparedness.
 
In Iraq,
  the troop surge has reached full strength. But does it have a chance of
  succeeding by September? David Martin will talk with one lieutenant general
  who is not optimistic.
 
Meanwhile, President Bush prepared to clash with
  other world leaders at the upcoming G-8 summit by announcing his own plan for
  battling climate change. Who’s backing it and who’s calling it
  just another smoke screen? Jim Axelrod will have the answers.
 
The environmental impact of 9/11 is still potentially
  being felt by tens of thousands of Americans: those who worked on rescue and
  cleanup after the attacks. Now, as Kelly Wallace will report, a third-wave of
  Ground Zero-related illnesses is appearing – in the form of cancer.
 
Hate e-mail Spam? You might be seeing a little bit
  less of it. Robert Alan Soloway, now known as one of the world’s top
  spammers, was arrested today. Bill Whitaker will tell you how this could
  affect your in-box.
 
Also tonight, we’ll take you inside where a
  sophisticated form of drug dealing takes place – and it looks just like
  a doctor’s office. It is one of thousands of “pill mills” across
  the United States.
  They are the subject of a CBS News investigation, which reveals the ease with
  which prescription drugs can be purchased – without a prescription. Chief
  investigative correspondent Armen Keteyian will report.
 
Finally, Byron Pitts will give you a look at the
  library dedicated today to Rev. Billy Graham. I hope you’ll join us for
  this and more,
 




Anthony Mason
CouricandCo@cbs.com
